[I]t is very possible that the other sources that Bloomberg felt were confirming its story were confirming something else: that China is trying to get into the hardware supply chain. Which is no doubt true, as US intelligence agencies have repeatedly warned in the past year, particularly with respect to mobile phones.

So it is possible that the reporters did an excellent job but ended up in the wrong place, with half a story but going down the wrong path. It is equally possibly that have got 90 per cent of the way there and Apple and Amazon are carefully using the last 10 per cent to issue careful denials.

BE11:10am

Yeah, both of those are plausible. Overall, though, the impression is bogeymen under the bed.

red no offer as yet but shares still well under hammerson (ill advised imo) offer

Which leaves us two questions: what price does this work, and what chance of a counter?

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Kempen's quite cautious.

red going to be hard to convince folks to take less than hammerson did less than a year ago
BE11:23am

With the 18H1 results revealing a 5.6% write-down in asset values (12% fall in NAV) this could be considered just the tip of the iceberg. Indeed with Intu’s +33 bps outward yield shift to 4.69% at 06/18A only really bringing them into line with the likes of Hammerson’s UK portfolio at 4.7% NIY; and the retail outlook not looking much healthier since then, there could well be a lot worse to come. With the stock currently trading at an eyewatering 57% discount to the 347p NAV/share reported at 06/18A, this implies 29% discount to gross assets based on the 49% LTV. With 29.9% already owned by the Consortium and a likely ownership threshold of 50%+1 shares needed, one could envisage a 15-20% premium to the current share price being required. A bid of around 175p gives an implied valuation write-down of c.25% which would appear to give some cushion for future valuation writedowns. We are yet to see if an offer materializes, but given that Brookfield would appear to already be working alongside intu’s largest shareholder, the Peel Group, we suspect a bid will be forthcoming, but at what level, we don’t know. All we know is that everything has price…

red as is its clear which side getting better deal
BE11:24am

And Citi on the possibility of a counter.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Our view is that the value of Intu could be attractive to others. Klepierre (where Simon Property Group currently owns 20.3%), this year made an informal approach for Hammerson that did not proceed. Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield are busy integrating Westfield which owns arguably the two best UK shopping centers. With Peel as the largest shareholder now in a consortium with Brookfield it would appear other bidders would have to venture down the less desirable hostile route.

BE11:25am

And the price table:

BE11:25am

Dec69 - Skeptic @Red, will it happen at all? ReF: Intu.

BE11:27am

With no details on pricing levels, it is difficult to be categorical either
way but for context, assuming a bid at 20-30% above the share price, implies a range of 180-195p, the top end of which is a 45% discount to 1H18 NAV (-35% vs NNNAV) and which implies an equiv yield of c.6.7%. Whether this would be sufficient to entice the c.70% of INTU’s register not owned by Peel/Olayan is hard to judge, but key to success will be getting Coronation, the Gordon Family and BlackRock on side given their combined c.37% interest.

red its sneaky. good biz. but sneaky all the same.
BE11:28am

Worth highlighting how much Brookfield's essential to this, mostly from the perspective of debt resculpting.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Numis again:

BE11:28am

Other than taking a counter-cyclical approach towards UK malls at what could prove to be the point of maximum pessimism, there are some clear and easy wins that Brookfield could achieve. Firstly, there is substantial low hanging fruit in INTU’s portfolio and second, there is significant potential upside from refinancing INTU’s expensive and inefficient debt structure. However, neither will be cheap to extract.

BE11:40am

Since the start of this year, we have upgraded our EBITDA forecasts for SKG by over 15% and for DS Smith by over 7% [ex-Europac]. Despite this, SKG’s share price is up just 12% while DS Smith’s share price is down 4% year-to-date [rights adjusted]. This implies that the valuation ratings of both stocks have de-rated. SKG is now trading on just 7.0x our 2018 EBITDA forecast, while DS Smith is trading on 8.0x.
Given the positive corrugated demand dynamics – both cyclical and structural (e-commerce – and the switch from plastics to paper-based packaging), we do not believe that this de-rating is justified. If anything, the sector should have re-rated to reflect the improvement in longer-term growth dynamics driven by these structural factors as well as the positive earnings momentum that is likely to continue well into 2019.

wayneJ @Flaneur - as far as I can see leading edge semi equip is ok?
BE11:41am

As for the Smith CMD, have Berenberg.

BE11:41am

Yesterday, DS Smith held a capital markets day (CMD) in London, which
saw management run through various aspects of the business. No new
material information was given, but we felt the presentation highlighted
how far the business has come in the past five years – the e-commerce
story offers material upside, innovation is genuinely impressive and
unique, and the US business has settled in well. The stock has been soft
since the start of the Europac acquisition process back in June, but we
think offers a diversified and cheap way to play both the e-commerce and
industrial consolidation themes. We remain buyers.

Hammerson PLC (HMSO:LSE): Last: 443.90, up 15.6 (+3.64%), High: 463.00, Low: 440.40, Volume: 3.85m
BE11:43am

Investment Overview: Hammerson is an owner-operator-developer of high quality retail property across the UK (56%) and Continental Europe, including France (19%) and Ireland (11%) and includes a unique exposure to the attractive Premium Outlets sector. UK retail is facing both structural and cyclical headwinds, but also a polarisation in performance whereby high quality assets are outperforming secondary. Whilst the operating environment in the UK remains challenging, this could ease once visibility around the UK’s exit from the EU improves.
■ Catalysts: Management is currently implementing its recent strategic review, which includes the disposal of its retail parks portfolio and a £300m share buyback programme. Following an indicative 635p approach from peer Klépierre earlier in the year, Klépierre’s six month lock-up is due to expire in the coming weeks. Risks: i) Consumer weaknesses and potential further retail and F&B administrations, especially in the UK; ii) Growth of online retail; iii) Property yield expansion; iv) Brexit.

While the recent profit warning saw the share price slide by c. 25%, we think this has only served to highlight ongoing risks which the company faces in the nearterm. Furthermore, despite the significant reset, the shares remain more expensive than some European Postal peers. As such we think the near-term risks for Royal Mail outweigh the opportunities and downgrade our rating to Sell from Neutral.

BE11:58am

(@Red: that's lovely. But why are they down this morning?)

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Although the impact of GDPR had been well flagged management have lowered the FY19 letter mail decline expectation to 7%. While the company remains confident that the trend decline range is still 4-6% over the medium term, we think it prudent to move to the lower end of the range, -6% from -5%, owing to the uncertain nature of the impact of this new regulation and the ongoing risk of accelerating declines given the UK remains a comparatively heavy user of letter mail currently.

BE11:59am

Although management have reset investors’ expectations for cost savings in FY19, it has an uphill battle to claw back that shortfall over the next 18 months on top of the necessary FY20 cost efficiencies, more than £300m in total by our estimation. We see significant risk that the target can might be missed which would result in a further profit warning in the next 12 months.
